0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-climatechange-accord-idUSKBN1370JX	Trump looking at fast ways to quit global climate deal: source	"
By Valerie Volcovici and Alister Doyle
| WASHINGTON/MARRAKESH
column2: Morocco

column1: WASHINGTON/MARRAKESH
column2: Morocco President-elect Donald Trump is seeking quick ways to withdraw the United States from a global accord to combat climate change
column3: a source on his transition team said
column4: defying broad global backing for the plan to cut greenhouse gas emissions.Since Trump's election victory on Tuesday
column5: governments ranging from China to small island states have reaffirmed support for the 2015 Paris agreement during climate talks involving 200 nations set to run until Friday in Marrakesh
column6: Morocco.Trump has called global warming a hoax and has promised to quit the Paris Agreement
column7: which was strongly supported by outgoing Democratic U.S. President Barack Obama.Trump's advisers are considering ways to bypass a theoretical four-year procedure for leaving the accord
column9: who works on Trump's transition team for international energy and climate policy.""It was reckless for the Paris agreement to enter into force before the election"" on Tuesday
column11: speaking on condition of anonymity.The Paris accord won enough backing for entry into force on Nov. 4
column12: four days before the election.U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry said on Sunday in New Zealand the Obama administration would do everything it could to implement the Paris accord before Trump takes office.The accord says in its Article 28 that any country wanting to pull out after signing on has to wait four years. In theory
column13: the earliest date for withdrawal would be Nov. 4
column15: around the time of the next U.S. presidential election.The source said the future Trump administration is weighing alternatives to accelerate the pull-out: sending a letter withdrawing from the 1992 international framework accord that is the parent treaty of the Paris Agreement; voiding U.S. involvement in both in a year's time; or issuing a presidential order simply deleting the U.S. signature from the Paris accord.

column1: Withdrawing from the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) would be controversial
column2: partly because it was signed by former Republican President George H.W. Bush in 1992 and approved by the U.S. Senate. The action also could antagonize many other countries. [L8N1DB41L]The UNFCCC sets a goal of avoiding ""dangerous"" man-made damage to the climate to avert more heat waves
column3: downpours
column4: floods
column5: extinctions of animals and plants and rising sea levels.The 2015 Paris Agreement is much more explicit
column6: seeking to phase out net greenhouse gas emissions by the second half of the century and limit global warming to ""well below"" 2 degrees Celsius (3.6 Fahrenheit) above pre-industrial times.Many nations have expressed hope that the United States will stay. But the host of the current round of climate negotiations
column7: Morocco
column8: said the pact that seeks to phase out greenhouse gases in the second half of the century was strong enough to survive a pullout.

column1: One party deciding to withdraw would not call the agreement into question
column2: Foreign Minister Salaheddine Mezouar told a news conference.In Beijing on Monday
column3: the foreign ministry spokesman
column4: Geng Shuang
column5: told a regular news briefing that China would like to continue working with all countries
column6: including the United States
column7: in the global fight against climate change. The agreement was reached by almost 200 nations in December and
column9: has been formally ratified by 109 representing 76 percent of greenhouse gas emissions
column10: including the United States with 18 percent.The accord seeks to limit rising temperatures that have been linked to increasing economic damage from desertification
column13: floods and rising sea levels.U.N. climate chief Patricia Espinosa declined to comment on the Trump source's remarks to Reuters.

column1: The Paris Agreement carries an enormous amount of weight and credibility
column2: Espinosa told a news conference.She said the United Nations hoped for a strong and constructive relationship with Trump.The Trump source said the president-elect's transition team is aware of the likely international backlash but said Republicans in the U.S. Congress have given ample warning that a Republican administration would take action to reverse course.""The Republican Party on multiple occasions has sent signals to the international community signaling that it doesn't agree with the pact. We've gone out of our way to give notice
column3: the source said.The source blamed Obama for joining up by an executive order
column4: without getting approval from the U.S. Senate.""There wouldn't be this diplomatic fallout on the broader international agenda if Obama hadn't rushed the adoption
column5: the source said. (Reporting by Valerie Volcovici in Washington and Alister Doyle in Morocco; Additional reporting by Sue-Lin Wong in Beijing; Editing by John Stonestreet and Clarence Fernandez)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKBN1380R9	Trump hires Republican insider
column2: conservative firebrand for White House	"

column1: By John Whitesides and Alana Wise
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON President-elect Donald Trump on Sunday picked Reince Priebus
column2: a Washington insider who heads the Republican National Committee
column3: as White House chief of staff
column4: signaling a willingness to work with Congress to advance his agenda when he takes office in January.But while giving the influential post to the low-key  Priebus
column5: Trump handed another senior White House job to rabble-rousing conservative media figure Stephen Bannon
column6: his campaign chairman who helped engineer his surprise victory on Tuesday over Democrat Hillary Clinton.Priebus is a friend of U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan
column7: who distanced himself from Trump during the campaign but embodies the Republican establishment in Washington and will play a critical role in shepherding Trump's agenda in Congress. Both Priebus and Ryan are from Wisconsin.But Bannon
column8: former head of the right-wing Breitbart News website
column9: has been fiercely critical of Ryan.Trump's statement announcing the appointments said Bannon and Priebus would be ""working as equal partners to transform the federal government
column10: with Bannon serving as chief strategist and senior counselor to the president.The White House chief of staff serves as a gatekeeper and agenda-setter for the president
column11: but Trump's statement mentioned Bannon's job first.""I am thrilled to have my very successful team continue with me in leading our country
column12: Trump said in a statement. ""Steve and Reince are highly qualified leaders who worked well together on our campaign and led us to a historic victory. Now I will have them both with me in the White House.""Before joining Trump's team
column13: Bannon spearheaded Breitbart's shift into a forum for the ""alt-right
column14: a loose online confederation of neo-Nazis
column15: white supremacists and anti-Semitics. Bannon's hiring by Trump's campaign this year signaled the businessman's dedication to operating outside the norms of Washington.Under Bannon's leadership
column16: the Breitbart site presented a number of conspiracy theories about Clinton as well as Republicans deemed to be lacking in conservative bona fides. Critics have accused Bannon of harboring anti-Semitic and white nationalist sentiments. In a 2007 court filing during divorce proceedings
column17: Bannon's former wife accused him of making anti-Semitic comments on at least three occasions.

column1: As head of Breitbart
column2: he repeatedly attacked the Republican Party establishment including Ryan
column3: alienating many veteran Republicans. Bannon showed his willingness to engage in brutal political tactics when he instigated the appearance before a presidential debate of three women who said they had been sexually abused by his Democratic rival's husband
column4: former President Bill Clinton.Trump
column5: who will succeed Democratic President Barack Obama on Jan. 20
column6: has been contemplating the candidates for top jobs in the White House and in various Cabinet positions since Tuesday's victory.Priebus' appointment could anger some hardline Trump supporters who were counting on Trump to keep his campaign promise to ""drain the swamp"" of business-as-usual Washington insiders.Priebus is a longtime Wisconsin political operative who was credited with marshaling party resources for Trump's White House bid. The Republican National Committee stepped in and ran most of the party's get-out-the-vote effort this year in the absence of such an operation by the Trump campaign.While some Republicans fled from Trump during the campaign
column7: Priebus was unwavering in his backing for the New York real estate developer.

column1: Priebus frequently traveled with Trump on the campaign trail and was seen as a positive force who helped rein in the unpredictable Trump in the closing weeks. Trump made his high regard for Priebus known on election night when he pulled him to the microphone to take a bow for his campaign efforts.BORDER WALL
Trump and his advisers already have hedged on some of his major campaign promises
column2: including on immigration
column3: healthcare and appointing a special prosecutor to investigate Clinton.Trump
column4: in an interview that aired on Sunday
column5: backed away from his promise to build a wall on the U.S.-Mexican border
column6: saying some areas could instead be ""fencing.""

column1: Trump
column2: whose pledge to force Mexico to pay for a border wall was a centerpiece of his White House
column3: said in ""certain areas"" he would accept fencing instead of a brick-and-mortar wall
column4: according to his interview with the CBS program ""60 Minutes.""""But certain areas
column5: a wall is more appropriate. I'm very good at this
column6: it's called construction
column7: there could be some fencing
column9: Trump said Americans alarmed by his election had nothing to fear. ""Don't be afraid. We are going to bring our country back. But certainly
column11: he said.Demonstrators in major U.S. cities took to the streets on Sunday for a fifth straight day to protest against Trump.Trump said in the interview that once he takes office
column12: he would remove immigrants with criminal records who are in the country illegally.During the campaign
column13: Trump said he would deport the estimated 11 million immigrants in the country illegally
column14: most of whom are Hispanic.Ryan on Sunday backed away from Trump's promise during the campaign of a ""deportation force"" to round up and deport immigrants in the country illegally.""We are not planning on erecting a deportation force. Donald Trump's not planning on that
column15: Ryan told CNN's ""State of the Union"" program. ""I think we should put people's minds at ease. That is not what our focus is. That is not what we're focused on. We're focused on securing the border."" (Additional reporting by Steve Holland and Howard Schneider; Writing by Will Dunham; Editing by Caren Bohan and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-protests-saturday-idUSKBN1370D2	U.S. protesters march against Trump presidency for fifth day	"
By Alexander Besant
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Demonstrators in major U.S. cities took to the streets on Sunday for a fifth straight day to protest President-elect Donald Trump
column2: whose campaign manager said President Barack Obama and Democrat Hillary Clinton should do more to support a peaceful transition.Following several nights of unrest
column3: crowds of people marched in parks in New York City
column4: San Francisco and Oakland
column5: California
column6: according to social media.A few thousand joined a march at the south end of Manhattan's Central Park
column7: beginning at a Trump property on Columbus Circle and walking toward the real estate mogul's skyscraper headquarters less than a mile (1.6 km) away.They chanted: ""Say it loud
column10: and held signs such as ""White silence = violence"" and ""Don't mourn
column11: organize."" One protester said demonstrators were reclaiming what the American flag he was holding stood for.""The flag means freedom of speech
column13: equal protection under the law and other values like diversity
column15: freedom of assembly and freedom of the press
column19: who was in New York for work. ""We're trying to reclaim the flag and push forward those values.""Thousands in several cities have demonstrated since the results from Tuesday's election showed Trump
column21: lost the popular tally but secured enough votes in the 538-member Electoral College to win the presidency
column22: surprising the world.Largely peaceful demonstrators in urban areas have said Trump threatens their civil and human rights. They have decried Trump's often inflammatory campaign rhetoric about illegal immigrants
column26: that the former reality TV star sexually abused women.Dozens have been arrested
column31: and a handful of police injured.

column1: 'LET'S MAKE WAVES'
In San Francisco on Sunday
column2: about 1
column3: 000 people marched through Golden Gate Park toward a beach where they chanted: ""Let's make waves."" They held signs such as ""I resist racism"" and ""Down with the Trumps."" Across the bay in Oakland
column4: thousands of protesters joined a festival-like atmosphere
column5: holding peace signs and blowing soap bubbles in the sunshine. Many had brought their children
column6: aiming to hold hands around the 3.4-mile (5.5-km) circumference of Lake Merritt in a popular urban park.Civil rights groups have monitored violence against U.S. minorities since Trump's win
column7: citing reports of attacks on women in Islamic head scarves
column8: of racist graffiti and of bullying of immigrant children. They have called on Trump to denounce the attacks.Trump said he was 'so saddened' to hear of instances of violence by some of his supporters against minorities
column9: according to a transcript released on Sunday of an interview with the CBS program '60 Minutes.'

column1: 'THIS MAN IS OUR PRESIDENT'
Kellyanne Conway
column2: Trump's campaign manager
column3: said on Fox News on Sunday that she was sure many of the protesters were paid professionals
column4: although she offered no proof.Suggesting a double standard
column5: Conway said on NBC's ""Meet the Press"" that if Clinton had won the election and Trump supporters had protested
column6: ""people would be freaking out that his supporters were not accepting election results.""""It's time really for President Obama and Secretary Clinton to say to these protesters: 'This man is our president
column7: '"" she said.

column1: Republican House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan told CNN on Sunday that protests were protected by the First Amendment as long as they were peaceful. Neither Obama nor Clinton has called for an end to the protests. Obama told Trump at the White House on Thursday that he was going to help Trump succeed
column2: ""because if you succeed
column3: then the country succeeds.""Clinton told supporters at a New York hotel on Wednesday: ""Donald Trump is going to be our president. We owe him an open mind and the chance to lead.""Trump on Sunday attacked the New York Times for coverage he said was ""very poor and highly inaccurate."" ""The @nytimes sent a letter to their subscribers apologizing for their BAD coverage of me. I wonder if it will change - doubt it?"" Trump wrote on Twitter.The newspaper published a letter in Sunday's editions from publisher Arthur Sulzberger and executive editor Dean Baquet
column4: not apologizing
column5: but thanking readers for their loyalty and asking how news outlets underestimated Trump's support.The Times plans to ""hold power to account
column6: impartially and unflinchingly"" during the Trump presidency
column7: they wrote. (Additional reporting by Alana Wise in Washington
column8: Beck Diefenbach in San Francisco and Noah Berger in Oakland
column9: Calif.; Writing by David Ingram; Editing by James Dalgleish and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-forprofitcolleges-idUSKBN1380UW	For-profit colleges could prosper under Trump: Barron's	"
For-profit education stocks have surged on expectations that President-elect Donald Trump and a Republican Congress may ease regulations imposed on the industry by the Obama administration
column2: Barron's said in a report.Stocks such as Grand Canyon Education
column3: DeVry Education Group and Capella Education rose about 14 percent last week. Trump won an upset victory in Tuesday's presidential election. Jeff Silber at BMO Capital Markets said Trump's election could be good news for for-profit education companies
column4: according to Barron's.A federal court trial in San Diego is set to begin on Nov. 28 over claims by former students of now-defunct Trump University that they were defrauded by a series of real estate seminars. A Trump lawyer has requested that the trial be delayed until after Trump's inauguration on Jan. 20. Trump denies the students' allegations.

column1: (Reporting by Chris Prentice in New York; Editing by Peter Cooney)"
5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-facebook-idUSKBN1380TH	Zuckerberg again rejects claims of Facebook impact on U.S. election	"
By Chris Prentice
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Facebook Inc chief executive Mark Zuckerberg again rejected the idea that the social network affected the U.S. presidential election
column2: saying late Saturday it is ""extremely unlikely"" news hoaxes changed the outcome.Ensnared in a string of content controversies in recent months
column3: Facebook has insisted that it is a technology company
column4: not a media firm. But scrutiny of the site has heightened since the surprise election of Republican Donald Trump on Tuesday
column5: with critics alleging the site helped spread lies via fake news stories and hoaxes. Zuckerberg has vehemently defended the network against such criticism
column6: calling the idea that Facebook affected the election  ""crazy"" at a conference on Thursday. He echoed that stance in his late Saturday post
column7: though he said the company would do more to prevent fake news. Such hoaxes represent a sliver of content shared on Facebook and because they are not limited to partisan views or politics
column8: it is unlikely they could have changed the election's outcome
column9: Zuckerberg said.""Of all the content on Facebook
column10: more than 99 percent of what people see is authentic
column12: noting the network's goal is to ""give every person a voice.""Still
column13: Facebook has launched work to enable people to flag hoaxes and fake news

column1: Facebook has faced a number of content controversies this year
column2: including international outcry after it removed an iconic Vietnam War photo due to nudity
column3: a decision that was later reversed. The thorniest content issues are decided by a group of top executives at Facebook.Questions over content policing have returned to the fore in the tense days since the election
column4: which has led to protests against Trump and his proposed policies in major U.S. cities.

column1: Ahead of the Nov. 8 election
column2: Facebook users saw fake news reports erroneously alleging that Pope Francis endorsed Donald Trump and that a federal agent who had been investigating Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton was found dead.Senior management have launched a conversation to examine Facebook's involvement in affecting opinions and votes
column3: The New York Times reported on Saturday
column4: saying a group of vice presidents and executives began discussing late Tuesday the company's role in the election's outcome. Facebook's policy team was called together and the firm plans to address staff concerns at a broader meeting
column5: the paper reported
column6: citing anonymous sources.

column1: Facebook representatives were not immediately available to comment on the report.""After the election
column2: many people are asking whether fake news contributed to the result
column3: and what our responsibility is to prevent fake news from spreading
column4: Zuckerberg said on Saturday. ""These are very important questions and I care deeply about getting them right."" (Reporting by Chris Prentice; Editing by Mary Milliken)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-trump-lawsuit-idUSKBN1380RH	Trump University asks for trial delay until after inauguration	"
By Tracy Rucinski
| CHICAGO
CHICAGO U.S. President-elect Donald Trump has requested that a trial over a lawsuit by former students of his now-defunct Trump University be put on hold until after the presidential inauguration
column2: according to a motion filed by his lawyer late Saturday.A trial in federal court in San Diego over former Trump University students' claims that they were defrauded by a series of real-estate seminars is scheduled to begin on Nov. 28
column3: but Trump lawyer Daniel Petrocelli said the president-elect needs to ""devote all of his time and attention to the transition process.""Trump is due to assume office on Jan. 20
column4: 2017. ""The 69 days until inauguration are critical and all-consuming

column6: arguing that the president-elect should not be required to stand trial during that time.Petrocelli had said at a hearing in San Diego on Thursday that he would request the delay
column7: though U.S. District Judge Gonzalo Curiel
column9: told lawyers he was not inclined to put off the six-year-old case further and encouraged the parties to settle.

column1: The lawsuit involves students who claim they were lured by false promises to pay up to $35
column2: 000 to learn Trump's real estate investing ""secrets"" from his ""hand-picked"" instructors.Trump owned 92 percent of Trump University and had control over all major decisions

column6: his taxes and corporate bankruptcies
column7: along with speeches and tweets.

column1: Curiel is presiding over two cases against Trump and the university. A separate lawsuit by New York's attorney general is pending.While presidents enjoy immunity from lawsuits arising from their official duties
column2: the U.S. Supreme Court has held that this shield does not extend to acts alleged to have taken place prior to taking office. (Reporting by Tracy Rucinski; Editing by Alan Crosby)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKBN1370LC	Clinton blames FBI's Comey for her defeat in call with donors	"
By Luciana Lopez and Ginger Gibson
| NEW YORK/WASHINGTON
NEW YORK/WASHINGTON Hillary Clinton blamed FBI director James Comey for her stunning defeat in Tuesday's presidential election in a conference call with her top campaign funders on Saturday
column2: according to two participants who were on the call. Clinton was projected by nearly every national public opinion poll as the heavy favorite going into Tuesday's race. Instead
column3: Republican Donald Trump won the election
column4: shocking many throughout the nation and prompting widespread protests.Clinton has kept a low profile since her defeat after delivering her concession speech on Wednesday morning. Clinton told her supporters on Saturday that her team had drafted a memo that looked at the changing opinion polls leading up to the election and that the letter from Comey proved to be a turning point. She said Comey's decision to go public with the renewed examination of her email server had caused an erosion of support in the upper Midwest
column5: according to three people familiar with the call.Clinton lost in Wisconsin
column6: the first time since 1984 that the state favored the Republican candidate in a presidential election. Although the final result in Michigan has still not been tallied
column7: it is leaning Republican
column8: in a state that last favored the Republican nominee in 1988.Comey sent a letter to Congress only days before the election announcing that he was reinstating an investigation into whether Clinton mishandled classified information when she used a private email server while secretary of state from 2009 to 2012. Comey announced a week later that he had reviewed emails and continued to believe she should not be prosecuted
column9: but the political damage was already done.

column1: Clinton told donors that Trump was able to seize on both of Comey's announcements and use them to attack her
column2: according to two participants on the call.While the second letter cleared her of wrongdoing
column3: Clinton said that it reinforced to Trump's supporters that the system was rigged in her favor and motivated them to mobilize on Election Day.The memo prepared by Clinton's campaign
column4: a copy of which was seen by Reuters
column5: said voters who decided which candidate to support in the last week were more likely to support Trump than Clinton.""In the end
column6: late breaking developments in the race proved one hurdle too many for us to overcome
column7: the memo concludes.

column3: who served as Clinton's finance chair
column4: said her campaign and the national party had raised more than $900 million from more than 3 million individual donors

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-britain-farage-idUSKBN1370P0	Britain's Brexit firebrand Farage meets Trump in New York	"
By Daniel Wallis and Kylie MacLellan
| NEW YORK/LONDON
NEW YORK/LONDON Leading Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage visited Donald Trump at his home on Saturday
column2: after suggesting he could act as a go-between to help smooth British relations with the U.S. president-elect.British Prime Minister Theresa May is not expected to meet the incoming leader until early next year and Farage has suggested her criticisms of Trump in the early days of the campaign could damage ties with Washington.    ""We're just tourists!"" Farage
column3: head of the UK Independence Party (UKIP)

column11: an American whose advocacy firm worked on the Brexit campaign

May - who spoke to Trump by phone on Thursday - and her predecessor David Cameron last year described Trump as ""divisive"" and ""wrong"" over his call to ban Muslims from entering the United States. At that time he was not considered likely to win the presidency.

Farage said he had been pleased at Trump's ""very positive reaction"" to the idea that a bust of former British prime minister Winston Churchill be put back in the Oval Office.He has also joked about sexual assault allegations against Trump

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-banks-regulation-idUSKBN1380H2	Obama officials work against time to wrap banking rules	"
By Patrick Rucker and Lisa Lambert
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON U.S. officials are striving to put finishing touches on a slew of banking rules before President Barack Obama leaves office and hands regulatory power to Donald Trump who has vowed to rewrite the existing financial rule book.President-elect Trump will take over on Jan. 20 and his fellow Republicans will have control of Congress and government agencies
column2: allowing the new administration to block or roll back many of the last-minute changes.But by completing far-advanced work on some banking standards in the next 10 weeks
column3: Obama officials would raising the chances that some elements of the regulatory framework will survive.Some rules are meant to flesh out the Dodd Frank Act of 2010 designed to prevent the next global financial crisis. Trump campaigned on a pledge to scrap the law but now he says only some provisions must go to lighten the regulatory burden.The Federal Reserve is working on rules to govern matters such as executive pay
column4: market stability and what investments Wall Street may hold.Last month
column5: Securities and Exchange Commission Chair Mary Jo White said her agency would ""in the near term"" finish a rule on one thorny issue: how mutual funds manage derivatives.The SEC and bank regulators have also for years struggled to finalize a rule that would tie more banker pay to the long-term health of their firms rather than short-term performance of Wall Street firms.With only about 40 working days until the handover
column6: it is not clear which
column7: if any
column8: of those standards will get across the finishing line.

column1: Just look at the calendar
column2: said Tom Quaadman of the Chamber of Commerce. ""These are intricate rules and there's not much time.""The executive pay rule exemplifies the challenge.Six federal agencies have a say on the compensation standard meant as part of Dodd Frank and a final draft has not yet been offered
column3: industry officials told Reuters.It would be nearly impossible to circulate a final rule and get the agencies to endorse it while still satisfying standards for clearing such paperwork
column4: several lobbyists who have opposed the rule said.Banking regulators declined to comment on when the compensation rule might be completed.

column1: NO TIME TO CHAT
Simple logistics also pose a challenge.New federal rules come into force once they have been published in the Federal Register and employees there typically need several days to typeset a rule.

That means Obama officials need to lodge paperwork with the Federal Register at the beginning of the inauguration week at the latest.Some sixteen copy editors are due to forego leave and be on hand in the coming weeks to process final rules expected from dozens of agencies
column2: said an official familiar with the operation
column3: but not authorized to speak to the media.""These days
column4: people do not spend a lot of time hanging around the coffee maker
column5: he said.Some freshly-minted rules also face the prospect of getting erased under a 1996 law known as the Congressional Review Act
column6: which allows Congress to block a regulation within 60 working days of being drafted.One such rule allows students who were defrauded by for-profit colleges to seek loan forgiveness. The Department of Education finalized it days before the Nov. 8 election
column7: meaning Republicans who have raised objections to it will have a chance to block it.President George W. Bush was the first to trigger the Review Act when he block labor regulations that his predecessor Bill Clinton had enacted at the end of his term. (Editing by Linda Stern and Tomasz Janowski)"
